Is merely vain, the lovers whose affections
Do sympathize together in full pleasure,
Debarred of this their summer sudden ends,
And care the winter to their former joys,
Breaths such a cold blast on their turtles bills;
Having not this, to shroud him forth his storms,
They straight are forced to make a separation,
And so live under those that rule o'er this.
The gallant, whose illustrious outside draws
The eyes of wantons to behold with wonder
Her rare shaped parts, for so he thinks they be,
Decked in the robes of glistering gallantry:
Having not this, attendant on his person,
Walks with a cloudy brow, and seems to all
A great contemner of society;
Not for the hate he bears to company,
But for the want of this ability:
Oh silver! thou that art the basest captive
Kept in this prison: how many pale offenders
For thee have suffered ruin; but o my gold
Thy sight's more pleasing, than the seemly locks
Of yellow haired Apollo, and thy touch
More smooth and dainty, than the down-soft white
Of ladies tempting breast, thy bright aspect
Dims the greatest luster of heaven's waggoner.
But why go I about to extol thy worth,
Knowing that poets cannot compass it;
But now give place my gold for here's a power
Of greater glory and supremacy
Obscures thy being, here sits enthronised
The sparkling diamond, whose bright reflection
Casts such a splendour on these other gems,
Amongst which he so majestical appears,
sp.stage: A flash of fire and Lightfoot ascends like a spirit.
sp.l: As if now my good angels guard me.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: Melior vigilantia somno.
Stand not amazed good man, for what appears
Shall add to thy content, be void of fears,
I am the shadow of rich kingly Croesus,
Sent by his greatness from the lower world
To make thee mighty, and to sway on earth
By thy abundant store, as he himself doth
In Elysium; how he reigneth there,
His shadow will unfold, give thou then ear.
In under-air where fair elizum stands
Beyond the river styled Acheron,
He hath a castle built of adamant;
Not framed by vain enchantment, but there fixed,
By the all burning hands of warlike spirits,
Whose windows are composed of purest crystal,
And decked within with Oriental pearls:
There the great spirit of Croesus' royal self,
Keeps his abode in joyous happiness;
He is not tortured there as poets feign
With molten gold and sulphury flames of fire,
Or any such molesting perturbation;
But there reputed as a demigod,
Feasting with Pluto and his Proserpine,
Night after night with all delicious cates,
With greater glory than seven kingdom's states.
Now further know the cause of my appearance,
The kingly Croesus having by fame's trump,
Heard that thy loved desires stand affected
To the obtaining of abundant wealth,
Sends me his shade, thus much to signify,
That if thou wilt become famous on earth,
He'll give to thee even more than infinite;
And after death with him thou shalt partake
The rare delights beyond the Stygian lake.

sp.speaker: Hog.
sp.p: Great Croesus' shadow may dispose of me to what he pleaseth.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: So speaks obediency.
For which I'll raise thy lowly thoughts as high,
As Croesus were in his mortality;
Stand then undaunted whilst I raise those spirits,
By whose laborious task and industry,
Thy treasure shall abound and multiply.

div.stage: Ascend Ascarion thou that art a powerful spirit and dost convert silver to gold, I say ascend and one me Cresus' shade attend to work the pleasure of his will. the player appears.

sp.speaker: Player
sp.l: What would then Croesus list to fill
Some mortals coffers up with gold,
Changing the silver it doth hold:
By that pure mettle if't be so,
By the infernal gates I swear,
Where Radamanth doth domineer:
By Cresus' name and by his castle,
Where winter nights he keepeth wassail;
By Demogorgon and the fates,
And by all these low country states;
That after knowledge of thy mind,
Ascarion like the swift paced wind,
Will fly to finish thy command.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: Take then this silver out of hand,
And bear it to the river Tagus,
Beyond th'abode of Archi Magus;
Whose golden sands upon it cast,
Transform it into gold at last:
Which being effected straight return,
And sudden too, or I will spurn
This trunk of thine into the pit,
Where all the hellish furies sit,
Scratching their eyes out quick begone.

sp.speaker: Player
sp.p: Swifter in course then doth the sun.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: How fairest thou mortal be? not terrified
At these infernal motions, know that shortly
Great Croesus' ghost shall in the love he bears thee,
Give thee sufficient power by thy own worth,
To raise such spirits.

sp.speaker: Hog.
sp.l: Croesus is much too liberal in his favour,
To one so far desertless as poor hog.

sp.speaker: Li
sp.l: Poor hog, oh speak not that word poor again,
Lest the whole apsetree of Croesus' bounty,
Cracked into shivers overthrow thy fortunes,
For he abhors the name of poverty,
And will grow sick to hear it spoken by those.
Whom he intends to raise; but see the twilight
Posteth before the chariot of the sun,
Brings word of his approach:
We must be sudden, and with speed raise up
The spirit Bazan: that can straight transform
Gold into pearl; be still and circumspect.

div.stage: Bazon ascend up from the treasure of Pluto, where thou didst at pleasure metamorphize all his gold into pearl, which 'bove a thousand fold exceeds the value, quickly rise to Cresus' shade, who hath a prize to be performed by thy strength.

sp.speaker: Bazon
sp.l: I am no fencer, yet at length
From Pluto's presence and the hall,
Where Proserpine keeps festival,
I'm hither come and now I see,
To what intent I'm raised by thee;
It is to make that mortal rich,
That at his fame men's ears may itch;
When they do hear but of his store.
He hath one daughter and no more;
Which all the lower powers decree,
She to one wealthy wedded be;
By which conjunction there shall spring,
Young heirs to hog whereon to fling:
His mass of treasure when a dies,
Thus Bazon truly prophecies:
But come my task I long to rear,
His fame above the hemisphere.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: Take then the gold which here doth lie.
And quick return it by and by;
All in choice pearl whither to go,
I need not tell you, for you know.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Indeed I do, and hog shall find it so.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: Now mortal there is nothing doth remain,
Twixt thee and thine abundance, only this
Turn thy eyes westward, for from thence appeareth
Ascarion with thy gold, which having brought
And at thy foot surrendered, make obeisance;
Then turn about and fix thy tapers westward,
From whence great Bazon brings thy orient pearl;
Who'll lay it at thy feet much like the former.

sp.speaker: Hog.
sp.p: Then I must make to him obeisance thus.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: Why so, in mean time Croesus' shade will rest
Upon thy bed, but above all take heed,
You suffer not your eyes to stray aside,
From the direct point I have set thee at:
For though the spirit do delay the time,
And not return your treasure speedily.

sp.speaker: Hog.
sp.l: Let the loss light on me, if I neglect
I overslip what Croesus' suit command.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.p: So now practise standing, though it be nothing agreeable to your hog's age, let me see among these writings is my nephew Haddit's mortgage; but in taking that it may breed suspect on us, wherefore this box of jewels will stand far better and let that alone, it is now break of day, and never by this the marriage is confirmed betwixt my cousin and great Croesus' friends daughter here, whom I would now leave to his most weighty cogitation
sp.l: So gentle sir adieu, time not permits
To hear those passions and those frantic fits;
Your subject to when you shall find how true,
Great Croesus' shade hath made an ass of you.

sp.speaker: Hog.
sp.p:
Let me now ruminate to myself why Croesus should be so great a favourer to me, and yet to what end should I desire to
know I think it is sufficient, it is so, and I would a had been so sooner, for he and his spirits would have saved me much labour in the purchasing of wealth; but then indeed it would have been the confusion of 2. or 3. Scriveners, which by my means have been properly raised: but now imagine this only a trick whereby I may be gulled; but how can that be? are not my doors locked, have I not seen with my own eyes the ascending of the spirits? have I not heard with my own ears the invocations wherewith they were raised? could any but spirits appear through so firm a floor as this is? 'tis impossible: but hark, I hear the spirit Ascarion coming with my gold, oh bountiful Croesus; I'll build a temple to thy mightiness.

div.stage: Enter young Lo. welthy and Peter.

sp.speaker: We.
sp.p: O Peter, how long have we slept upon the hogshead?

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.p: I think a dozen hours my lord, and 'tis nothing, I'll undertake to sleep sixteen, upon the receipt of two cups of muskadine.

sp.speaker: We.
sp.p: I marvel what's become of Haddit and Lighfoote?

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.p: Hang 'em flinchers they slunk away as soon as they had drunk as much as they were able to carry, which no generous spirit would a done in deed.

sp.speaker: We.
sp.p: Yet I believe had. had his part, for to my thinking the seller went round with him when 'a left us, but are we come to a bed yet? I must needs sleep.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.p: Come softly by any means, for we are now upon the threshold of my master's chamber, through which I'll bring you to mistress Rebecka's lodging, give me your hand and come very nicely.

sp.speaker: We.
sp.p: Where art Peter.

sp.speaker: We.
sp.p: Where's this noise Peter canst tell?

sp.speaker: Hog,
sp.p: I hear the voice of my adopted son in law.

sp.speaker: We.
sp.p: Why Peter wilt not answer me?

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.p: O my lord above, stand still, I am fallen down at least 30. fathom deep, if you stand not still till I recover and have lighten a candle, you're but a dead man.

sp.speaker: Hog.
sp.p: I am robbed, I am undone, I am deluded, who's in my chamber?

sp.speaker: We.
sp.p: 'Tis I, the lord your son that shall be, upon my honour I came not to rob you.

sp.speaker: Hog.
sp.p: I shall run mad, I shall run mad.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Why then 'tis my fortune to be terrified with madmen.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.p: Where are you my lord?

sp.speaker: Hog.
sp.p: Here my lady? where are you rogue when thieves break into my house?

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.p: Breaking my neck in your service a plague on't.

sp.speaker: We.
sp.p: But are you robbed indeed father hog, of how much I pray?

sp.speaker: Hog.
sp.p: Of all, of all; see here, they have left me nothing but 2. or 3. rolls of parchment, here they came up like spirits, and took my silver, gold, and jewels; where's my daughter?

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.p: She's not in the house sir? the street doors are wide open.

sp.speaker: We.
sp.p: Nay 'tis no matter where she is now? she'll scarce be worth a 1000. pound and that's but a tailor's prize.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Then you'll not have her sir?

sp.speaker: We.
sp.p: No as I hope to live in peace.

sp.speaker: Hog.
sp.p: Why be't so, be't so, confusion cannot come in a more fitter time on all of us: oh bountiful Croesus, how fine thy shadow hath devoured my substance.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.p: Good my lord promise him to marry his daughter, or 'a will be mad presently, though you never intend to have her.

sp.speaker: We.
sp.p: Well father hog, though you are undone, your daughter shall not be, so long as a lord's can stand her in any stead: come you shall with me to my lord and father, whose warrants we will have for the apprehending of all suspicious lives, and though the labour be infinite, you must consider your loss is so.

sp.speaker: Hog.
sp.p: Come, I'll do any thing to gain my gold.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.p: Till which be had, my fare will be but cold.

div.stage: Enter Haddit, Rob. Lightfoot, and priest.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: Now Mr. parson we will no further trouble you, and for the tying of our true love knot, here's a small amends.

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.l: 'Tis more than due sir, yet I'll take it all,
Should kindness be despised, good will would fall.
Unto a lower ebb, should we detest
The grateful giver's gift,

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: It's true indeed, good morrow honest parson.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: Yet if you please, sir John will back surrender
The overplus of what you now did tender.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.p: O by no means, I pray thee friend, good-morrow.

sp.speaker: Li
sp.l: Why if you please sir John to me restore,
The overplus I'll give it to the poor.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: O pardon sir, for by our worships leave,
We ought to give from whence we do receive.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: Why then to me sir John.

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.p: To all a kind good morrow.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.p: A most fine vicar, there was no other means to be rid of him: but why are you so sad Rebecka?

sp.speaker: Re.
sp.l: To think in what estate my father is?
When he beholds that he is merely gulled.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: Nay be not grieved, for that which should rather give you cause of content, for 'twill be a means to make him abandon his avarice, and save a soul almost incurable: but now to our own affairs, this marriage of ours must not yet be known lest it breed suspicion, we will bring you rebeck a unto Atlas his house, whilst we two go unto the old lord Welthies, having some acquaintance with his son in law Carracus, who I understand is there, where no question but we shall find your father proclaiming his loss, thither you shall come some what after us, as it were to seek him, where I doubt not but so to order the matter, that I will receive you as my wife, from his own hands.

sp.speaker: Re.
sp.p: May it so happy prove.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: Amen say I, for should our last trick be known, great Croesus' shade would have a coniured time on't.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: 'Tis true, his castle of adamant would scarce hold him: but come this will be good cause for laughter hereafter.
sp.l: Then we'll relate how this great bird was pulled,
Of his rich feathers, and most finely gulled.

div.stage: Enter old lo. welthy with Car. ma. and Albert.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: More welcome Carrucus, then friendly truce
To a besieged city all distressed;
How early this glad morning are you come
To make me happy, for pardon of your offence
I've given a blessing, which may heaven confirm,
In treble manner on your virtuous lives.
And may our lives and duty daily strive,
To be found worthy of that loving favour,
Which from your reverent age we now receive,
Without desert, or merit.
sp.stage: Enter young Wel. Hogge and Peter.

sp.speaker: We.
sp.l: Room for a desirer of justice, what my sister Maria;
Who thought to have met you here?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: You may see brother, unlooked for guest's proof often troublesome.

sp.speaker: We.
sp.p: Well, but is your husband there any quieter than 'a was?

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Sir, I must desire you to forget all injuries, if, in not being myself, I offered you any.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: I'll see that peace concluded.

sp.speaker: We.
sp.p: Which I agree to, for patience is a virtue father hog.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Was it you son that cried so loud for justice?

sp.speaker: We.
sp.p: Yes marry was it, and this the party to whom it appertains.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: O my most honoured lord I am undone, robbed this black night of all the wealth and treasure, which these many years I have hourly laboured for.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.p: And who are those have done this outrage to you?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: O knew I that, I then my lord were happy.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.p: Come you for justice then, not knowing 'gainst whom the course of justice should extend itself?
sp.l: Nor yet suspect you none?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: None but the devil.

sp.speaker: We.
sp.p: I thought 'a was a cheater, ere since I heard two or three templars swear at dice the last Christmas, that the devil had got all.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.p: My kind acquaintance. Joy to thy good success.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Noble, and freeborn Haddit, welcome.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: Mr. hog good-day.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: For I have had a bad night on't

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p:
Sickness is incident to age, what be the writings ready
to be sealed, we entreated last day.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Yes I think they are, would the scrivener were paid for the making them.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: 'A shall be so, though I do't myself, is the money put up as I appointed?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Yes 'tis put up, confusion cease the receivers.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: Heaven bless us all, what mean you sir?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: O sir, I was robbed this night of all I had,
My daughter to is lost, and I undone.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: Marry, God forbid, after what manner I pray.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: O to recount sir will breed more ruth,
Then did the tale of that high Trojan Duke,
To the sad fated Carthaginian Queen.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.p: What exclamations that?

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: What you will grieve at coz,
Your worshipful friend m. hog is robbed.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.p: Robbed, by whom or how?

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: O there's the grief, 'a knows not whom to suspect.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.p: The fear of hell o'ertake them whatsoever they be: but where's your daughter, I hope she is safe.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Thanks heaven, I see she's now so, where hast thou been my girl?

sp.speaker: Re.
sp.p: Alas sir, carried by amazement, I know not where, pursued by the robbers forced to fly as mad affright, through all the city streets to seek redress, but that lay fast asleep in all men's houses, nor would lend an ear to the distressed.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: O heavy accident, but see you grieve too much,
Being your daughter's found, for th'other loss;
Since 'tis the will of heaven to give and take,
Value it as nothing, you have yet sufficient
To live in blessed content, had you no more
But my small mortgage for your daughter here;
Whom I have ever loved in dearest affection,
If so you please so much to favour me,
I will accept her spite of poverty,
And make her jointure of some store of land,
Which by the loss of a good aged friend
Late fell to me, what is't a match or no.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: It is.
Then I'll have witness on't, my lord and gent.
Please you draw near, to be here witnesses
To a wished contract, twixt this maid and I.

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.p: We all are willing.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Then in the presence of you all, I give my daughter freely to this gent. as wife, and to show how much I stand affected to him for dowry with her, I do back restore his mortgaged lands, and for their loves I vow, ever hereafter to detest, renounce, loath and abhor all slavish avarice:
sp.l: Which doth ascend from hell, sent by the devil,
To be 'mongst men the actor of all evil.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: A blessed conversion.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: A good far unexpected, and now gentlemen,
I do invite you all to feast with me
This happy day, that we may altogether
Applaud his good success, and let this day be spent,
In sports and shows with gladsome merriment:
Come blessed converted man we'll lead the way,
As unto heaven I hope we shall.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Heaven grant we may.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Come my Maria and repentent friend,
We three have tasted worst of misery,
Which now add joy to our felicity.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: We three are happy we have gained much wealth,
And though we have done it by a trick of stealth,
Yet all I trust are pleased, and will our ill acquit,
Since it hath saved a soul was hells by right.

sp.speaker: We.
sp.l: To follow after then, our lot doth fall,
Now rhyme it Peter.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.p: A good night to all.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: Now expectation hath at full received
What we late promised, if in ought we have pleased,
'Tis all we sought to accomplish, and much more
Than our weak merit dares to attribute
Unto itself, till you vouchsafe to deign
In your kind censure, so to gratify
Our trivial labours:
If it hath pleased the judicial ear,
We have our authors wish, and void of fear
Dare ignorant men, to show their worst of hate.
It not detracts, but adds unto that state
Where desert flourisheth.
We'll rest applauded in their derogation,
Though with an hiss they crown that confirmation:
For this our author saith, if't prove distasteful,
He only grieves you spent two hours so wasteful:
But if it like, and you affect his pen,
You may command it when you please again.
